facts.text: Appellant filed writ petition No. 226 of 1963 in Allahabad High Court, Lucknow Bench, seeking to quash order of State Transport Authority dated March 20/21, 1963.

State Transport Authority rejected appellant's revision petition against decision of Regional Transport Authority limiting the number of stage carriages under S. 47(3) of the Motor Vehicles Act, 1939.
Regional Transport Authority passed order under S. 47(3) on November 17, 1962, limiting number of stage carriages.
Allahabad High Court Division Bench dismissed writ petition by judgment dated November 11, 1966.
Appellant is an existing operator on the route.
Appellant never approached the Regional Transport Authority in the first instance.

legal_issues.text: Whether an order under S. 47(3) of the Motor Vehicles Act, 1939, limiting the number of stage carriages, is subject to revision under S. 64-A.
Whether existing operators have a right to representation before Regional Transport Authority passes order under S. 47(3).
Whether an existing operator is a 'person aggrieved' entitled to file revision under S. 64-A against order under S. 47(3).

petitioner_arguments.text: An order under S. 47(3), whether quasi-judicial or administrative, affects existing operators on the route and their representations must be considered by Regional Transport Authority before passing such order.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: S. 47(1) and S. 47(3) of Motor Vehicles Act, 1939

petitioner_arguments.text: Revision lies under S. 64-A against order under S. 47(3) and should not have been dismissed on ground that no revision lay; State Transport Authority should hear revision on merits.

respondent_arguments.text: No revision lies at instance of existing operator under S. 64-A as he cannot be called an aggrieved person.
Even if revision lies, appellant not entitled to relief as he never approached Regional Transport Authority in first instance.
Decision under S. 47(3) is tentative and can be revised by Regional Transport Authority.

court_reasoning.text: Sub-s. (3) of S. 47 does not expressly say whether representations can be made by persons already providing transport facilities; expression 'matters mentioned in sub-section (1)' refers to matters in cls. (a) to (f) of sub-s. (1), not right of representation.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Representations under S. 47(1) bring matters in cls. (a) to (f) to notice of Regional Transport Authority.

court_reasoning.text: S. 64-A is wide in terms; order under S. 47(3) is an 'order' within S. 64-A as it binds authorities in dealing with permit applications.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Revision lies against order under S. 47(3).

court_reasoning.text: Existing operator can be aggrieved by order under S. 47(3) depending on facts; such order affects future working on route and has repercussion on existing operators.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No ground for denying right to approach revisional authority if prejudicial.

court_reasoning.text: High Court examined merits and found order under S. 47(3) good; no glaring mistake shown; order passed in 1962, demand likely increased over five years; no interference under Art. 136.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Discretion under Art. 136 not to interfere.

holdings.text: Revision lies under S. 64-A against an order passed under S. 47(3) of the Motor Vehicles Act, 1939.
An existing operator can be a person aggrieved by an order under S. 47(3) if prejudicial to his interests.
No need to decide if existing operators entitled to be heard before order under S. 47(3); right of revision conferred by S. 64-A not affected.

precedents_cited.case_name: Abdul Mateen v. Ram Kailash Pandey
precedents_cited.relevance: Order under S. 47(3) binds Regional Transport Authority and State Transport Authority in permit applications; did not decide if S. 64-A allows varying such order.

statutes_cited.name: Motor Vehicles Act, 1939
statutes_cited.relevance: S. 47 governs procedure for considering stage carriage permits, including limiting number under sub-s. (3); S. 64-A provides for revision against orders of Regional Transport Authority where no appeal lies.

outcome.summary: Appeal by special leave dismissed; no interference with High Court order in exercise of discretion under Art. 136 of the Constitution.

key_quotes.text: S. 64-A is very wide in terms the only condition necessary for filing a revision is that it should be against an order made by the Regional Transport Authority and against which no appeal lies.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Establishes that revision lies under S. 64-A against S. 47(3) order.

key_quotes.text: An order under s. 47(3) affects the future working on a route and we are of the view that such an order would have repercussion on the working of the existing operators, whether for their good or not.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Confirms existing operators can be aggrieved.
